immediate_care: Rest is your body's best medicine right now - try to get extra sleep
Stay well hydrated with water, herbal teas, and warm broths
Use throat lozenges or gargle with warm salt water for sore throat relief
Consider zinc supplements within the first 24 hours (consult pharmacist for dosing)
Use a humidifier or breathe steam from a hot shower to ease congestion
symptom_relief: For stuffy nose: saline nasal rinses can provide gentle relief
Honey can soothe coughs and sore throats (not for children under 1 year)
Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen for aches
Avoid smoking and secondhand smoke to prevent irritation
common_cold.when_to_seek_help: See a healthcare provider if symptoms worsen after a week, you develop a high fever, or experience severe headache or sinus pain

immediate_care: Bed rest is crucial - your body needs energy to fight the virus
Drink plenty of fluids to prevent dehydration and help thin mucus
Antiviral medications may help if started within 48 hours - contact your doctor
Take your temperature regularly and monitor symptoms closely
symptom_relief: Acetaminophen or ibuprofen can help reduce fever and body aches
Warm compresses can soothe muscle pain and headaches
Throat lozenges or warm salt water gargles for throat discomfort
Light, easily digestible foods when you feel up to eating
influenza.when_to_seek_help: Seek immediate medical care for difficulty breathing, persistent high fever, severe headache, or signs of dehydration

immediate_care: Hydration is your top priority - sip fluids slowly and frequently
Start with clear fluids: water, clear broths, electrolyte solutions
Rest your stomach by avoiding solid foods initially
Gradually reintroduce foods following the BRAT diet (bananas, rice, applesauce, toast)
symptom_relief: Avoid dairy products, fatty foods, spicy foods, and high-fiber foods
Stay away from alcohol, caffeine, and sugary drinks
Small, frequent meals are better than large ones
Probiotics may help restore healthy gut bacteria
gastroenteritis.when_to_seek_help: Seek medical care if you can't keep fluids down, show signs of severe dehydration, or have blood in vomit/stool

immediate_care: Find a dark, quiet room and try to rest or sleep
Apply a cold compress to your forehead or the back of your neck
Gentle neck and shoulder massage may provide some relief
Take prescribed migraine medication as early as possible in the attack
symptom_relief: Dim the lights and avoid bright screens
Minimize noise and strong odors
Try relaxation techniques like deep breathing or meditation
Stay hydrated, but avoid large amounts of liquid at once
migraine.when_to_seek_help: Contact your doctor if migraines become more frequent/severe, or if you experience sudden severe headache unlike your usual pattern

immediate_care: Practice deep breathing exercises - inhale for 4, hold for 4, exhale for 6
Use grounding techniques: name 5 things you can see, 4 you can touch, 3 you can hear
Try progressive muscle relaxation starting from your toes up to your head
Remind yourself that anxiety attacks are temporary and will pass
symptom_relief: Reduce or eliminate caffeine, as it can worsen anxiety symptoms
Regular exercise can significantly reduce anxiety levels
Maintain consistent sleep patterns and aim for 7-9 hours nightly
Consider meditation, yoga, or mindfulness practices
anxiety_disorder.when_to_seek_help: Seek professional help if anxiety interferes with daily life, work, or relationships, or if you have thoughts of self-harm
